title: Computer Science Club Hosts Coding Marathon
author: Code Wright
summary: Students spent 12 hours straight designing apps, websites, and games during the school’s annual Code-A-Thon — caffeine and creativity flowed freely.
content:
The LakeView Technology Academy’s Computer Science Club held its highly anticipated annual Code-A-Thon on Saturday, September 28, drawing dozens of students eager to test their programming skills in a collaborative and high-energy environment. The 12-hour event, which began at 8:00 a.m. and concluded just before midnight, challenged participants to design and develop original software projects under tight time constraints.

Throughout the day, teams of two to five students worked diligently on a wide array of projects, ranging from web-based productivity tools to interactive video games. The atmosphere inside the school’s commons area was one of intense concentration and excitement. Students huddled around laptops, surrounded by whiteboards filled with diagrams, UI mockups, and snippets of hastily written pseudocode. Periodic bursts of laughter and applause punctuated the sound of rapid keyboard clicks as participants celebrated breakthroughs and solved difficult bugs.

The event opened with remarks from Computer Science Club president Ben Taylor, who emphasized the importance of innovation and teamwork. “The Code-A-Thon isn’t just about writing code—it’s about learning how to think critically and solve problems creatively,” he said. Club advisor Mrs. Larson echoed those sentiments, noting that the event provides a valuable opportunity for students to engage in real-world applications of classroom concepts. “This kind of hands-on collaboration builds both technical skill and leadership,” she remarked.

As the day progressed, students showcased remarkable ingenuity. One team developed CampusConnect, a mobile app designed to help students find study partners based on shared classes and available time slots. Another group created EcoSort, a web-based educational game teaching players how to recycle correctly. Judges, including members of the school’s STEM faculty and local software engineers, evaluated each project on criteria such as originality, user experience, and technical execution.

When the final scores were tallied, CampusConnect was awarded first place for its innovative design and real-world practicality. Team members received Raspberry Pi development kits and certificates of achievement. In her closing remarks, Mrs. Larson commended all participants for their dedication and perseverance, stating, “The level of professionalism and creativity displayed today was extraordinary. Every team demonstrated what makes LakeView students stand out.”

Following the success of this year’s Code-A-Thon, the Computer Science Club has already begun discussing plans to expand the event into a district-wide competition in 2026. With growing student interest and community support, organizers hope the event will continue to foster collaboration, technical excellence, and a passion for innovation among future generations of young programmers.
